entry.title: More GitHub content (#741)
entry.content:
More GitHub content  (#741)

* begin git guides

* include git workflow text

* finish draft for git-overview

* borrow content from git overview for commit page

* begin commit page

* draft of git commit

* add content for installing git

* prune down metadata

* rework first sentence around git commits

* move info about how commits work into proper section

* more detail about why its bad to change history

* add git log to list of commands

* add related commands to git commit

* fix italics

* turn bullets into section headers

* add 4 new page outlines

* draft of git add content

* draft for git clone

* add git remote -v term to git overview

* draft of git pull guide

* start git remote page

* draft of git init

* fix typo in installation

* remove metadata for git init

* refine git init

* refine git add

* tidy git clone

* refine git pull

* more exact language around pull force

* Add installation notes for windows

* Update installation notes for GH Desktop

* Update installation notes for macOS

* Update installation notes for Linux

* update git add page with more detail in steps and shell example

* move add shell to under when do you use

* add git clone shell example

* add shell example of commit

* add shell example to git init

* add shell example of git pull

* remove the git remote page

* add the git remote page

* add empty push and status pages

* add content for git remote and git push

* add git status draft

* Update git-status.md

* Add git pull best practice note to push

* Remove note about commit structure

Although important, this seemed out-of-place for this guide. It makes more sense to include this in git add or git commit. Feel free to revert if viewed differently

* Update git-guides/git-push.md

Co-Authored-By: Parker Brown <17183625+parkerbxyz@users.noreply.github.com>

* Update git-guides/git-remote.md

* Update git-guides/git-remote.md

Co-Authored-By: Parker Brown <17183625+parkerbxyz@users.noreply.github.com>

* Update git-guides/git-status.md

Co-Authored-By: Parker Brown <17183625+parkerbxyz@users.noreply.github.com>

* Update git-guides/git-status.md

Co-Authored-By: Parker Brown <17183625+parkerbxyz@users.noreply.github.com>

* fill in details for push options

* update fork image

Co-authored-by: Dylan Stark <dylanastark@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: a-a-ron <a-a-ron@github.com>
Co-authored-by: Parker Brown <17183625+parkerbxyz@users.noreply.github.com>

entry.title: Improve and modernize the submodule cheat sheet (#727)
entry.content:
Improve and modernize the submodule cheat sheet (#727)

* Use correct spelling for the Git system

Since commit 2de9b71138 (Documentation: the name of the system is 'Git', not
'git', 2013-01-21) in git.git, the Git community settled on using 'Git'
as the correct spelling for the systems as a whole.

Let's use the correct spelling in the cheat sheets.

* Submodule cheatsheet: use --recurse-submodules in clone

The `--recursive` flag has been removed from the `git clone`
documentation since commit bb62e0a99f (clone: teach --recurse-submodules
to optionally take a pathspec, 2017-03-17) in git.git.

Let's use the documented flag `--recurse-submodules` instead,
which tells `clone` to recursively clone all submodules
along with the superproject.

* Submodule cheatsheet: add more 'git diff' options

First, remove the `--cached` option as this option is only useful
if the changes to the submodule are staged beforehand.

Second, list all 3 `git diff` options related to submodules:
- `--submodule` (defaults to --submodule=log)
- `--submodule=short (default for `git diff`)
- `--submodule=diff`

Third, remove the `sdiff` alias as `git diff --submodule=diff` does the
same thing but is a builtin command.

* Submodule cheatsheet: add details to 'Clone' section

Introduce `git submodule update --init` as a way to clone and checkout
submodules if you forgot `--recurse-submodules` when cloning.

A following commit will introduce a new section 'Pulling Superproject
Updates' to show how to update an already cloned repo that has
submodules.

Also introduce the `--recursive` flag, which is needed if any submodule
itself has submodules.

* Submodule cheatsheet: improve 'Pulling in Subproject Updates'

- Add `git commit` after `git submodule update --remote` to complete
  the update in the superproject
- Instruct readers that `git submodule update <path>` wants the *path*
  to a submodule, not its name (important if submodules are not at the
  root of the repo).
- By default, `git submodule update --remote` will pull the `master`
  branch of the remote repository, not the default branch on the remote.
- Introduce `git submodule set-branch`, added in Git 2.22, to
  change the default branch for `git submodule update --remote`.

* Submodule cheatsheet: add 'Pulling Superproject Updates' section

When pulling in a repository that has submodules, the default behaviour of
`git pull` is to fetch the submodule, but not to update the working
directory of the submodule.

This leads to a very confusing situation, since just after the pull
the working directory of the submodule is not in sync with the commit
recorded in the superproject.

To complete the update, a separate `git submodule update` is required,
or `git pull` must be called with the `--recurse-submodules` flag.

Also, if the superproject changes the URL of the submodule,
`git submodule sync` is required to synchronize the URL to the local
.git/config and .git/modules/<name>/config configuration files.

* Submodule cheatsheet: add 'Changing branches' section

When changing branches in a project that has submodules, the default
behaviour of `git checkout` is to not update the working
directory of the submodule.

This leads to a very confusing situation, since just after the checkout
the working directory of the submodule is not in sync with the commit
recorded in the superproject.

To complete the update, a separate `git submodule update` is required,
or `git checkout` must be called with the `--recurse-submodules` flag.

* Submodule cheatsheet: improve 'Making changes to a Subproject'

- Make it clearer that best practice is to make the changes in a
  separate *clone* of the submodule repository
- Add a config to make `git push` default to
  `--recurse-submodules=on-demand`

* Submodule cheatsheet: add submodule.recurse to 'Helpful Configs for Submodules'

The submodule.recurse config is super useful as it makes all Git
commands (except `clone`, as of Git 2.25) automatically use the
`--recurse-submodules` flag if they support it, so mention that config
setting.

Also, add `--global` to the status.submoduleSummary `git config` call,
for uniformity.

* Submodules cheatsheet: mention that submodule.recurse needs Git 2.15 for `git pull`

Co-Authored-By: Aaron Stewart <a-a-ron@github.com>

Co-authored-by: Aaron Stewart <a-a-ron@github.com>
